statement.text: Large bore arterial access refers to percutaneous or surgical access using sheaths typically 12-24F for procedures such as transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR), endovascular aortic repair (EVAR), and percutaneous ventricular assist devices. Successful large bore access requires careful preoperative planning including iliofemoral assessment (CT angiography), appropriate patient selection, and expertise in both access and closure techniques. The 'preclose' technique using suture-mediated devices enables percutaneous closure of large arteriotomies.
statement.formal: Large Bore Access: Preoperative CTA for iliofemoral assessment → Minimum diameter criteria (TAVR: 5-5.5mm, EVAR: varies by device) → Ultrasound-guided access → Preclose with 2 ProGlide devices (perpendicular orientation) → Serial dilation → Insert large sheath → Complete procedure → Remove sheath → Tie preclose sutures | Alternative: Surgical cutdown if anatomy unfavorable

explanation.intuition: Large bore access is like trying to park a big truck in a small garage - you need to make sure the road (your arteries) is wide enough, straight enough, and smooth enough for the truck (the large sheath) to get through without causing damage. The preclose technique is like putting stitches in the garage door frame BEFORE the truck goes through, so you can easily sew it back together after.
explanation.key_insight: The key to successful large bore access is patient selection. A patient with a 6mm diameter calcified, tortuous iliac artery is a setup for disaster with an 18F TAVR sheath. Preprocedural CT angiography is mandatory to measure vessel diameters, assess calcification, and plan the approach. Sometimes the right answer is 'don't do it percutaneously.'
explanation.technical_details: Preprocedure Planning: (1) CT angiography of iliofemoral system; (2) Measure minimum vessel diameter (at narrowest point, not just at access site); (3) Assess calcification (circumferential calcium is high-risk); (4) Assess tortuosity (severe angulation may prevent device delivery); (5) Rule out occlusive disease, aneurysm, or prior stents. Access Technique: (1) Ultrasound-guided CFA puncture; (2) Confirm CFA position with angiography through small sheath; (3) Deploy two ProGlide devices at 10-2 o'clock and 4-8 o'clock orientations; (4) Secure sutures outside skin without tying; (5) Exchange for stiff wire (e.g., Lunderquist, Amplatz Super Stiff); (6) Serial dilation if needed; (7) Advance large sheath; (8) Complete procedure; (9) Remove sheath over wire (maintain access); (10) Tie preclose sutures; (11) Confirm hemostasis angiographically if needed. Minimum Diameters: TAVR 14-18F typically requires ≥5.5mm, EVAR varies by device manufacturer (check IFU).
common_misconceptions: Any femoral artery can accommodate large bore access - vessel diameter, calcification, and tortuosity matter
One ProGlide device is enough for large bore - typically need 2 devices at perpendicular orientations
Preclose always works - surgical backup is essential, cutdown may be needed
CT isn't necessary if the pulse is good - you MUST assess the entire iliofemoral system

definitions_glossary.preclose_technique: Deploying suture closure devices before large sheath insertion
definitions_glossary.iliofemoral_assessment: CT imaging evaluation of iliac and femoral arteries for access planning
definitions_glossary.minimum_vessel_diameter: Smallest arterial diameter along access route, limiting factor for sheath size
definitions_glossary.surgical_cutdown: Open surgical exposure as alternative to percutaneous access

contraindications: Severe circumferential calcification at access site
Prior surgery or stents limiting access

preprocedure_imaging.modality: CT angiography of aorta, iliac, and femoral arteries
measurements: Minimum diameter of external iliac artery
Minimum diameter of common iliac artery

criteria.evar: Per manufacturer IFU, typically 7-9mm for main body

sheath_insertion.wire: Stiff wire required (Lunderquist, Amplatz Super Stiff)
sheath_insertion.dilation: May need serial dilation for tight arteries
sheath_insertion.advancement: Gentle, steady pressure with fluoroscopic guidance
sheath_insertion.troubleshooting: If resistance, consider iliac conduit or alternative access

steps: Remove large sheath over wire (maintain access)
Advance preclose sutures down with pusher
Tie first suture while assistant applies proximal pressure
If still bleeding, additional ProGlide through wire access
closure.bailout: If preclose fails, surgical repair over wire access

surgical_cutdown.technique: Open femoral exposure, direct sheath insertion, primary closure

iliac_conduit.indication: Small/diseased iliofemoral with adequate iliac above
iliac_conduit.technique: Surgical graft to common iliac, access through graft

alternative_access.indication: Bilateral iliofemoral disease precluding femoral access

complications.prevention: Proper patient selection, gentle technique, adequate vessel diameter
Monitor limb perfusion during procedure, don't occlude artery too long

complications.management: Antibiotics, drainage, may need surgical repair

definition.@value: Technique of obtaining and closing large-diameter (≥12F) arterial access for advanced endovascular procedures

sources.citation: Mwipatayi BP, et al. TAVR access site management: best practices. J Vasc Surg.
Society for Vascular Surgery. Guidelines on management of arterial access for TAVR and EVAR.

learning_objectives: Describe the preprocedural assessment for large bore access
Perform preclose technique for large bore arteriotomy closure
Select appropriate patients for percutaneous vs surgical access
clinical_pearls: CT angiography is MANDATORY before large bore access - no exceptions
Two ProGlide devices at perpendicular orientations are standard for ≥14F
If the vessel is too small, calcified, or tortuous - do a cutdown
Always have surgical backup available - preclose doesn't always work
The minimum diameter along the entire route matters, not just at the access site

medicalCode.description: Insertion of infusion device into femoral artery, percutaneous approach
